item.description:
Join us on the gorgeous waters of Knubble Bay, Maine...

Knubble Bay Cottage overlooks the water at Georgetown Island, Maine.

This beautiful post-and-beam cottage operates almost completely off the grid and has endless miles of kayaking right from its door.

ENJOY the Height of Fall in Maine!

There is wind- & solar-powered lighting, and hand-pumped water.

It has a propane refrigerator and gas cooking range, as well as a wood stove for heat.

Rent or bring your kayak for 2 gorgeous nights on the waters of Knubble Bay!

The cottage has its own private dock. We can kayak in the bays and coves with seals and ospreys to keep us company. Explore local shops and beaches, and eat lobster fresh from the boat at one of Georgetown Island’s picturesque fishing hamlets. Paddling destinations include Robinhood Cove (with a genuine shipwreck), Beal Island, Goose Rock Passage, Five Islands and Reid State Park.  Several nearby islands are on the Maine Island Trail and are maintained by the Maine Island Trail Association.

And if you don't want to paddle, there's no shortage of other things to do including hiking and biking and touring Georgetown Island including Reid State Park.

Cost: $119 per person includes 3 days/2 nights, Friday through Sunday, October 19-21. Beds are in a large coed bunk room w/ mattresses and futons - please be flexible. (Arrive whenever you want on Friday if you can't get off early.)

Payment is due when you RSVP, or contact me directly to send a check. Your spot is reserved when payment is received.

LIMIT: 10 people

Last year's trip was a fun and amazing group experience! There will be beautiful views, good food, beer, wine, and lots of laughter!


Kayaking: The plan will be to ride the incoming tide north where the protected waters take us to rocky passages, scenic bays, and several secluded islands where we can have lunch and stretch our legs.

Wetsuits are recommended at this time of year. If you don't have one, Seaspray rents them for $5/day.

Or, enjoy the cabin and surrounding area all day if you don't want to paddle.

What to Bring: sleeping bag or bedding, flashlight, ear plugs, towels, soap/dish soap, paper towels, toilet paper, matches, extra D-cell batteries for the lamps, all food including spices, condiments, etc., extra drinking water (in case of issues with the pump), a sun shower, your cell phone car charger, a kayak and a bicycle if you like.

Meals: we'll bring food and share cooking together.

What is

provided: all kitchen utensils, firewood, mattresses, books, games, a great view, ospreys, seals, and miles of paddling!

There is an indoor toilet but no indoor shower. Bring a sun shower (you can buy one cheaply at any camping store or dept.). We'll heat water on the gas stove and you can enjoy a fresh-air, hot-water bathing experience in the outdoor shower!

What not to bring: Pets, flammable lanterns, candles.

Reid State Park is a 15-min drive - with sandy beaches.

Seaspray Kayaking - rents sea kayaks for only $35/day w/ free delivery to the cottage. ($5/day wetsuits.)

Talk to Scott at Seaspray if you want to rent a boat or gear: 207-751-3450

Directions: I-95 North to exit 44 for I-295 North/Portland. I-295 to exit 28 for Route 1/coastal route. Follow US Rt.1 through Bath across the Kennebec River Bridge. Just beyond the bridge, turn right onto Rt. 127 (towards Reid State Park). Proceed 5.8 miles to Robinhood Road. Take a left onto Robinhood Road, proceed 1 mile, turn left onto Webber Road. If you have passed Robinhood Meeting House Restaurant, you have gone too far. Follow Webber Road 1.2 miles and turn right onto Jewett Road. Follow Jewett Road, turning right at each fork, approximately 0.6 miles turn left at the KBC sign. The cottage is less than 2 hrs from Portsmouth.

Tides: Sat: L-9:15am, H-3:30pm; Sun: L-10:15am, H-4:30pm. 54F

AS A CONDITION OF ATTENDING THIS MEETUP, YOU AGREE TO hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer and his heirs, and all members and participants of the Seacoast Outdoors Meetup group from any and all claims for injury, illness, death, and/or property damage including those caused by negligence, ignorance, inexperience and other reasons. You also agree to assume all mental, physical, financial, and/or other risk associated with this meetup. Kayaking, camping, hiking, bicycling, and other activities pose inherent risks and dangers. Participation in these activities is voluntary and dependent upon your own personal judgment. As organizer I make no claims regarding any expertise for this outing and am not a Maine Kayak Guide.   -Larry Pilla
item.name: Knubble Bay Cottage Weekend
